title: REDCap at UWI Cave Hill
text:
Introduction
This book is an operations and maintenance guide for the REDCap service available at The University of the West Indies, Cave Hill campus. In early 2026, the operations of this REDCap installation pass from the CaribData funded project to the Cave Hill campus. This book is provided to provide operational continuity.
REDCap is at heart an online data collection platform. In practice though it is much more—it is an institutional service that supports research governance, ethics, data protection, and day-to-day academic work. When it runs quietly, nobody notices. When it fails, the consequences are immediate and visible. This guide documents how the service is actually run, with less information on how it is built and configured.
So the focus here is operational: routine tasks, decision points, risks, and recovery. The intent is not to explain how REDCap works for end users, nor to replicate official REDCap documentation. Instead, this guide captures the local knowledge required to keep the service stable, compliant, and trustworthy over time.
crumbs: 1  REDCap at UWI Cave Hill

title: REDCap at UWI Cave Hill
text:
Who this guide is for
The book is written for staff who inherit responsibility for the REDCap service, whether as system administrators, IT support, research office staff, or technical managers. It assumes general technical competence, but not prior familiarity with this specific REDCap instance or its history.
Some sections will be relevant to day-to-day operations. Others exist purely for rare but high-impact situations—incidents, security events, migrations, or staff turnover. Those moments when undocumented knowledge causes the most harm.
crumbs: 1  REDCap at UWI Cave Hill

title: REDCap at UWI Cave Hill
text:
How to use this book
This is not a book to be read cover to cover.
Each chapter is designed to stand alone and be consulted when needed. Operational checklists, configuration notes, and governance decisions are intentionally explicit. Because of the dip-in-and-out nature of the book we do repeat ourselves from chapter to chapter. Where appropriate, the guide distinguishes between:

what must be done to keep the service functioning,
what should be done to keep it well-governed, and
what could be improved if capacity allows.
crumbs: 1  REDCap at UWI Cave Hill

title: REDCap at UWI Cave Hill
text:
Scope and limitations
This guide documents the REDCap service as operated in this institutional context. It does not attempt to cover every REDCap feature, nor does it override official REDCap guidance or institutional policy. Where local practice diverges from defaults or recommendations, that divergence is made explicit and justified.
The guide should be treated as a living document. REDCap versions change, institutional policies evolve, and staff roles shift. The book is hosted through GitHub, and is public, so the next group to manage this REDCap instance can keep the site live and up-to-date.






Note



This is a static site built using Quarto and hosted via GitHub Pages. A basic knowledge of these systems will be needed to maintain the site. Those skills are not part of this handover document.

We view operational handover as a process, and this book is one part of that process. The original CaribData team - led by Professor Ian Hambleton - will remain available for questions going forwards.

title: 2  The REDCap Service Overview
text:
2.1 Introduction
This document describes the REDCap service operated for The University of the West Indies (UWI), Cave Hill, and the institutional responsibilities associated with its operation.
REDCap is a secure, web-based data capture platform developed and licensed by Vanderbilt University under a non-profit end-user licence agreement. UWI participates in the REDCap Consortium and operates REDCap in accordance with Vanderbilt’s licensing terms, governance expectations, and community standards.
The UWI REDCap instance has been project-managed by the CaribData project and hosted on dedicated infrastructure provided by HIPAA-Vault .

3  REDCap Administration Overview
text:
3.1 Introduction
This section describes how user access and REDCap projects are administered for the University of the West Indies (UWI) REDCap service.
The REDCap administrative functions ensure that REDCap is used appropriately, securely, and in line with licensing, governance (especially data governance, which differs between Caribbean territories), and data protection requirements.

title: 3  REDCap Administration
text:
3.3 User account management
All user accounts are created and managed centrally. Requests for access are submitted via the designated REDCap support email and should clearly state:

the user’s affiliation,
intended use of REDCap,
whether they are joining an existing project or proposing a new one.

Administrators are responsible for ensuring that:

accounts are issued only to identifiable individuals;
accounts use appropriate institutional or approved email addresses;
access is removed or suspended promptly when affiliation ends;
account expiration dates are used where appropriate.

Shared or generic accounts are not permitted, as they undermine auditability and accountability.

title: 3  REDCap Administration
text:
3.4 Project creation and approval
New projects require administrative approval before they are created or activated. This step ensures that projects are correctly classified (for example, research versus operational use) and that basic governance expectations are understood by project owners.
Administrators should confirm that project managers understand their responsibilities for user management, data handling, and compliance within their projects.

title: 3  REDCap Administration
3  REDCap Administration Overview
text:
3.3 Elevated permissions and features
Certain REDCap functions require explicit administrative approval because they introduce additional risk or system-level impact. These include API access, activation of external modules, enabling mobile data collection, and approval of advanced project features.
Administrative decisions should follow the principle of least privilege, with additional privileges documented at all times.

title: 3  REDCap Administration Overview
text:
3.4 Oversight and routine checks
As part of normal operations, administrators should periodically review user accounts, project status, and system logs to identify inactive users, stalled projects, or unusual patterns of data export or access. Those periodic reviews should be part of a system maintenance log.
These checks support institutional accountability and reduce the risk of unnoticed misuse.

title: 4  Types of Administrative Requests
text:
4.1 Introduction
This section describes how support for the UWI REDCap service is provided, including how requests are handled, triaged, and escalated.
The support model reflects the boundaries between REDCap software ownership (Vanderbilt University), local service operation (UWI and CaribData), and infrastructure hosting (HIPAA Vault).

title: 4  Types of Administrative Requests
4  Types of Administrative Requests
text:
4.4 Common administrative support procedures
This section documents the most frequent administrative actions carried out by REDCap administrators in response to user support requests.
Procedures assume administrator-level access and familiarity with REDCap terminology. They focus on what to do and what to check, rather than user-interface walkthroughs that may change between REDCap versions.

4.4.1 Resetting a user password
Password resets are required when users cannot log in or did not receive their original account email (occassionally, the automated REDCap email has been redirected by a user’s spam filter).
Breadcrumb
Control Center → Browse Users → (select user) → Reset password / Send password reset email
Procedure

Locate the user account.
Confirm the account is active and the email address is correct.
Trigger a password reset or reset email.
Advise the user to check inbox and spam or quarantine folders.

If the user does not receive the email, verify outbound email configuration and consider institutional mail filtering.


4.4.2 Extending or resetting a user account expiration date
User accounts may expire automatically based on institutional or administrative policy. Expired accounts prevent login but retain audit history.
Breadcrumb
Control Center → Browse Users → (select user) → Edit user settings → Account expiration
Procedure

Locate the user account.
Edit the expiration date or remove it where appropriate.
Save changes and confirm the account is active.
Advise the user of their updated account expiration

Expiration dates should be applied deliberately and reviewed periodically.


4.4.3 Suspending or reactivating a user account
Accounts may be suspended due to staff changes, temporary inactivity, or security concerns.
Breadcrumb
Control Center → Browse Users → (select user) → Suspend user / Reactivate user
Procedure

Change the account status as required.
Confirm the updated status has taken effect.

Suspension is reversible and preserves audit history. It is preferred to deletion in most cases.


4.4.4 Resending account creation emails
Users occasionally report not receiving their initial account creation email.
Breadcrumb
Control Center → Browse Users → (select user) → Resend account email
Procedure

Confirm the account exists and is active.
Verify the email address.
Resend the account or password email.
Ask the user to check spam or quarantine folders.

Repeated failures have generally turned out to be email filtering rather than a REDCap issue.


4.4.5 Creating a new user account
New accounts are created centrally to ensure traceability and appropriate use.
Breadcrumb
Control Center → Add New User
Procedure

Enter the user’s name, email address, and institutional affiliation.
Set an expiration date if required.
Save the account and confirm the email notification is sent.

Shared or generic accounts should not be created. Groups of new users can be created in a single proedure by using the Create Users (Bulk Upload) facility. This involves completing a REDCap Excel template and uploading that template.


4.4.6 Approving project creation
Requests for new projects require administrative approval.
Breadcrumb
Control Center → To-Do List → Pending requests → Review request
Procedure

Review the stated project purpose.
Confirm whether surveys, public links, API access, or sensitive data are involved.
Approve or reject the request accordingly.

Approval implies that baseline governance expectations have been communicated.


4.4.7 Moving a project to production
Projects must be reviewed before moving from development to production. Best practice dictates that projects should only be moved to Production once the database has been designed and carefully tested. Reverting a project to Development after data-entry has started risks data loss.
Breadcrumb (project initiates)
Project → Setup → Move project to Production
Breadcrumb (administrator approves)
Control Center → To-Do List → Pending requests / Production move requests → Approve
Procedure

Confirm testing is complete.
Verify that instruments and settings are stable.
Approve the move and document the action if non-routine.

Production status has audit and governance implications and should not be reversed lightly.


4.4.8 Approving API tokens
API access enables automated data exchange and introduces additional risk.
Breadcrumb (project initiates)
Project → Applications → API → Request token
Breadcrumb (administrator approves)
Control Center → API token requests → Approve
Procedure

Review the justification for API access.
Confirm the requester understands scope and security responsibilities.
Approve the token if appropriate.
Encourage least-privilege use and periodic review.



4.4.9 Activating external modules
External modules extend REDCap functionality but may affect system behaviour.
Breadcrumb (system level)
Control Center → External Modules → Manage modules
Breadcrumb (project level)
Project → External Modules → Enable module
Procedure

Review the purpose and documentation of the module.
Confirm compatibility with the current REDCap version.
Assess performance and security implications.
Enable and monitor usage.

Not all modules are appropriate for all installations.

title: 4  Types of Administrative Requests
text:
4.5 REDCap Control Center: administrator orientation
The REDCap Control Center is the primary workspace for system administrators. It provides access to system-wide settings, approvals, and oversight tools.
Administrators should understand the structure of the Control Center rather than memorising individual menu items.

4.5.1 Core administrative areas

User management
Control Center → Browse Users
Control Center → Add New User
Project governance and approvals
Control Center → Project requests / Pending requests
System configuration
Control Center → System Configuration / General Configuration
Email configuration
Control Center → Email Configuration
External modules
Control Center → External Modules
Logs and audit support
Control Center → Logging / System logs



4.5.2 Administrative mindset
The Control Center is intentionally powerful. Most changes made here affect all users and projects.
Administrators should act conservatively, document non-routine actions, and favour reversible changes wherever possible.

title: 5  REDCap Emails
text:
5.1 Introduction
Email is a fundamental dependency for REDCap, enabling user notifications, survey distribution, and automated alerts. At the same time, it presents governance and security risks that require careful management.
This section documents how email is used within the UWI REDCap service and the principles governing its configuration.

title: 5  REDCap Emails
text:
5.3 Universal FROM address considerations
A universal FROM address can provide consistency and simplify mail routing, but it also introduces a dependency on the continued availability of the associated domain and mailbox.
Where a universal FROM address is used, it should be institutionally owned, monitored, and reviewed periodically. Personal or externally funded mailboxes should be avoided.
Changes to the FROM address or SMTP configuration should be treated as service-level changes and tested accordingly.
The REDCap universal email address is: redcap@cavehill.uwi.edu.

title: 5  REDCap Emails
text:
5.4 Governance and risk management
Email should always be treated as an insecure communication channel. As such, sensitive personal or health data must never be included in email bodies or attachments.
Project-level alerts and survey invitations should reference records using identifiers rather than names, and project teams should be reminded of these constraints during project approval.
These practices align with both Vanderbilt guidance and the security assumptions of the hosting environment.

title: 5  REDCap Emails
text:
5.5 Testing and change management
Any change to email configuration should be followed by systematic testing, including account notifications, survey invitations, and alerts from a test project. It is highly recommended that these changes be tested on the development server before making the change on the production server.
Email issues are often invisible until users report failures, so short-term monitoring after changes is essential to ensure continuity of service.

title: 6  System Maintenance
text:
6.1 Introduction
This section describes how routine maintenance and upgrades are managed for the UWI REDCap service.
The REDCap application runs on a dedicated Linux virtual machine hosted by HIPAA Vault. This is a fixed-capacity, managed environment. Maintenance activities therefore require coordination between REDCap administrators and the hosting provider and should follow predictable, documented procedures.

title: 6  System Maintenance
text:
6.3 Routine system checks
To Complete

title: 6  System Maintenance
text:
6.4 REDCap version upgrades
REDCap releases frequent updates, including feature enhancements, bug fixes, and occasional security patches. The UWI policy is to keep the system reasonably up to date while avoiding unnecessary disruption to users.
Upgrades should be informed by Vanderbilt release notes and changelogs. Not all releases require immediate action, but security-related updates should be prioritised.

title: 6  System Maintenance
text:
6.5 Pre-upgrade preparation
Before any upgrade, administrators must coordinate with the HIPAA Vault team to ensure a recent server snapshot is available. This provides a rollback option if the upgrade fails or introduces unexpected behaviour.
At all times, new REDCap versions should be tested on a development or staging environment before being applied to the production system. Testing should focus on core functionality, authentication, surveys, alerts, and any enabled external modules.
Administrators should also notify users in advance if an upgrade is expected to cause service interruption.

title: 6  System Maintenance
text:
6.6 Performing upgrades
REDCap upgrades are typically applied by administrators with appropriate access to the server environment. In some cases, HIPAA Vault may assist with server-level changes required to support the upgrade, such as PHP or database adjustments.
Upgrades should be scheduled during periods of low usage where possible and should be followed immediately by basic functional checks.

title: 6  System Maintenance
6  System Maintenance
text:
6.8 Unplanned maintenance and incidents
Occasionally, unplanned maintenance may be required in response to security vulnerabilities, system instability, or hosting issues.
In such cases, the priority is service stability and data protection. Administrators should document the issue, actions taken, and outcomes, and communicate clearly with users if service availability is affected.

title: 7  System Backups
text:
7.1 Introduction
This section describes how backups and data recovery are handled for the UWI REDCap service.
Backups are a shared responsibility across infrastructure, application, and project levels. No single mechanism provides complete protection against data loss, and it is important to understand what each layer does — and does not — provide.

title: 7  System Backups
text:
7.3 Application-level safeguards in REDCap
REDCap includes built-in safeguards that support data integrity, including audit logs, change tracking, and controlled data exports. These features support transparency and traceability but do not replace backups. They are most useful for understanding what changed and when, rather than for restoring lost data.

title: 7  System Backups
text:
7.4 Project-level data exports
Project teams are responsible for exporting and retaining copies of their own data in accordance with institutional policies and research governance requirements. Regular project-level data exports are the most reliable way for projects to ensure continuity, particularly for long-running studies or operational systems. Exports should be stored securely (think encrypted) outside the REDCap environment.
Administrators should remind project owners that REDCap is a live system, not a long-term archival solution.

title: 7  System Backups
text:
7.5 Recovery scenarios
Different types of data loss require different responses.
In the case of accidental record deletion or user error, recovery may not be possible unless the project team has retained recent exports.
In the case of system-level failure, administrators may work with HIPAA Vault to restore the server from a recent snapshot. This process restores the system to a previous state and may result in loss of recent changes.
Clear communication with affected users is essential in all recovery scenarios.

title: 7  System Backups
text:
7.6 Testing and assurance
While full restoration tests are rare, administrators should periodically review backup arrangements with the hosting provider and confirm that snapshots are being taken as expected.
Understanding backup scope and limitations is a key part of service continuity planning.

title: 7  System Backups
text:
7.7 End-of-service considerations
If the REDCap service is migrated, decommissioned, or transferred to another institutional owner, data retrieval timelines become critical.
Project teams should be given clear notice and sufficient time to export their data. After hosting services are terminated, unretrieved data may become permanently inaccessible.

title: 8  System Security & Governance
text:
8.1 Introduction
This section describes the security structure of the UWI REDCap service and the shared responsibilities that underpin it. Robust security is a key feature of our system, designed to allow researchers and others to confidently collect and manage individual-level information as part of the research work.
Security in REDCap is not a single control or technology. It is a layered model that combines infrastructure protections, application-level safeguards, and institutional governance. Weakness at any one layer can undermine the others.

title: 8  System Security & Governance
text:
8.3 Authentication and access control
Access to REDCap is granted through individual user accounts. Each account is tied to a specific person and email address and is subject to role-based permissions within projects.
Administrators are responsible for ensuring that access is appropriate, proportionate, and time-limited where necessary. Project managers are responsible for managing access within their own projects.
Shared accounts, excessive permissions, and dormant users represent security risks and should be actively avoided.

title: 8  System Security & Governance
text:
8.4 Data protection and privacy
REDCap is designed to support secure data capture, including for sensitive research and operational data. However, the platform does not absolve users or the institution of their data protection responsibilities.






WarningProject teams are responsible for their own data security



Project teams are responsible for ensuring that their use of REDCap complies with applicable ethics approvals, data protection legislation, and institutional policies.


Administrators should pay particular attention to features that increase exposure risk, such as public surveys, API access, and external modules.

title: 8  System Security & Governance
text:
8.5 Email and indirect data exposure
Email is an essential but inherently insecure component of REDCap workflows. While email enables notifications and survey distribution, it should never be used to transmit sensitive data.
Administrators should ensure that project teams understand this limitation and design alerts and invitations accordingly. This is a recurring risk area and merits ongoing attention.

title: 8  System Security & Governance
text:
8.6 Incident awareness and response
Not all security incidents are technical breaches. Misconfigured permissions, accidental data exports, or inappropriate sharing can all constitute security events.
When a potential incident is identified, the priority is to contain risk, preserve evidence, and escalate appropriately within institutional governance structures. Documentation of incidents and responses supports learning and accountability.

title: 8  System Security & Governance
text:
8.7 Security as an ongoing process
Security is not static. Changes in usage patterns, staffing, or external threats can alter the risk profile of the service over time.
Regular review of user access, project configurations, and system behaviour helps ensure that security controls remain effective and proportionate.

title: 9  Useful Checklists
text:
9.1 Introduction
This section provides practical checklists to support continuity of the UWI REDCap service.
The aim is not to replace judgement, but to reduce reliance on memory during routine tasks, staff transitions, or stressful situations.

title: 9  Useful Checklists
9  Useful Checklists
text:
9.4 Post-upgrade checklist
After an upgrade, administrators should verify that core functionality is intact. This includes:

login,
project access,
survey functionality,
alerts, and
any enabled external modules.

Unexpected behaviour should be investigated promptly, and rollback options considered if stability is compromised.

title: 9  Useful Checklists
text:
9.5 Incident response checklist
When something goes wrong, the immediate goals are to stabilise the system, protect data, and communicate clearly.
Administrators should identify whether the issue is user-related, application-level, or infrastructure-level, and escalate accordingly. Actions taken should be documented, even if the resolution is straightforward.

title: 9  Useful Checklists
text:
9.6 Staff transition and handover
REDCap continuity depends on more than documentation. When administrative responsibility changes, access credentials, vendor contacts, and institutional knowledge must be deliberately transferred. This guide is intended to support that process.

title: 9  Useful Checklists
text:
9.7 Periodic review
At least annually, administrators should step back and review whether the service configuration, support model, and governance arrangements still reflect how REDCap is actually being used.
Quiet drift is a common source of operational risk. Periodic review helps bring assumptions back into line with reality.

3  REDCap Administration Overview
text:
3.2 Administrative role and scope
REDCap administrators (who have the highest level of front-end access) are responsible for the configuration and oversight of the REDCap system itself. This role is distinct from that of project managers, who control activity within individual projects.
Administrative responsibilities include user account management, approval of projects and elevated functions, and oversight of the project lifecycle.

3.2.1 User account management
All user accounts are created and managed centrally. Requests for access are submitted via the designated REDCap support email—currently: redcap@cavehill.uwi.edu and should clearly state:

the user’s affiliation,
intended use of REDCap,
whether they are joining an existing project or proposing a new one.







NoteUser Sponsors



If a current project owner wants to add new system users, the email request should come from the project owner. That project owner would then be setup as a user sponsor and have access to a sponsor dashboard for automating certain user related activities.


Administrators are responsible for ensuring that:

accounts are issued only to identifiable individuals;
accounts use appropriate institutional or approved email addresses whenever possible;
access is removed or suspended promptly when affiliation ends;
account expiration dates are used in all cases.

Shared or generic accounts are not permitted, as they undermine auditability and accountability.


3.2.2 Project creation and approval
New projects require administrative approval before they are created or activated. This step ensures that projects are correctly classified (for example, research versus operational use), certain additional project-level metadata are collected, and that basic governance expectations are understood by project owners.
Administrators should confirm that project owners/managers understand their responsibilities for user management, data handling, and compliance within their projects. This responsibility work has generally been performed as part of the onboarding process - whenever a new user is created or a new project created.


3.2.3 Project lifecycle control
Administrators control key transitions in the project lifecycle, including:

approval of project creation;
moving projects from development to production;
approval of project copies;
archiving of completed or inactive projects;
deletion of projects, where permitted by institutional policy.

Project deletion is irreversible and should only occur after confirming data retention and governance requirements.

title: 5  REDCap Emails
text:
5.2 Role of email in REDCap
REDCap uses email to support core functions such as account creation, password management, survey invitations, reminders, and Alerts & Notifications configured within projects.
While email delivery is essential for normal operation, REDCap does not require a fixed or branded sender address, provided that outbound email routing is correctly configured.

title: 8  System Security & Governance
text:
8.2 Layered security model
The UWI REDCap service operates within three distinct security layers.
At the infrastructure layer, HIPAA Vault provides physical data centre security, operating system hardening, managed firewalls, encrypted network connections, and continuous monitoring. This layer protects the server environment but does not control how REDCap is configured or used. HIPAA Vault has GDPR certification.
At the application layer, REDCap provides role-based access control, audit logging, data validation, and secure authentication mechanisms. These features govern how users interact with data but depend on correct configuration. You can read more about the REDCap security features here.
At the institutional layer, UWI defines who may use REDCap, for what purposes, and under what conditions. Policies, training, and administrative oversight sit at this layer and are critical to effective security.

title: 6  System Maintenance
text:
6.2 Responsibility boundaries
System maintenance spans multiple layers, each with a different owner.

HIPAA Vault is responsible for the underlying infrastructure, including server hardware, operating system patching, firewall management, and network security.
UWI, through its REDCap administrators, is responsible for the REDCap application itself, including configuration, upgrades, testing, and user communication.
Vanderbilt University provides the REDCap software and documentation but does not perform upgrades, host the system, or provide operational support.

Understanding these boundaries is essential when planning or responding to maintenance activities.

title: 7  System Backups
text:
7.2 Infrastructure-level backups
HIPAA Vault provides infrastructure-level backups and snapshots as part of its hosting service. These backups are designed to support disaster recovery in the event of server failure, corruption, or major incidents. Infrastructure backups typically capture the state of the server at a point in time. They are not intended for routine data retrieval or fine-grained restoration of individual records or projects. Retention periods and recovery windows are finite and governed by the hosting agreement. In the event of contract termination or prolonged service disruption, data availability is time-limited.

title: 10  Standard REDCap Wording for Re-Use
text:
10.2 Standard service description
The following text may be used in institutional documentation, presentations, or onboarding materials:

REDCap (Research Electronic Data Capture) is a secure, web-based software platform developed by Vanderbilt University and hosted for The University of the West Indies by CaribData. It is designed to support the collection and management of research and operational data through validated data capture, audit trails, and controlled data export.

title: 9  Useful Checklists
text:
9.2 Routine operational checks
At regular intervals, administrators should confirm that the service is functioning as expected. This includes checking:

user access,
reviewing recent support requests for patterns, and
ensuring that system messages or warnings have not been overlooked.

These checks are especially important in a fixed-capacity hosting environment, where gradual increases in usage may have cumulative effects.

title: 10  Standard REDCap Wording for Re-Use
section: 10.4 Standard wording for ethics and research governance submissions
text:
10.4 Standard wording for ethics and research governance submissions
The following text may be used by project owners when describing REDCap in ethics applications, research protocols, or governance documentation.

Description of the REDCap platform REDCap (Research Electronic Data Capture) is a secure, web-based application designed to support data capture for research and operational projects. It enables users to build and manage electronic data collection instruments, deploy surveys and forms, manage role-based access to data, and export data to standard statistical formats.
REDCap is developed and maintained by Vanderbilt University and made available to institutions through a non-profit licensing agreement. The University of the West Indies participates in the REDCap Consortium and operates REDCap in accordance with the consortium’s governance and licensing requirements.
Data security and access controls
The REDCap platform includes multiple security features designed to protect personal and sensitive data, including:

role-based user access controls;
user authentication and permission management;
full audit logging of data entry, modification, and export activity;
encrypted data transmission using HTTPS;
configurable project-level security settings.

Access to each REDCap project is restricted to authorised users approved by the project owner. Users are granted the minimum level of access necessary for their role.
Data storage and governance
The UWI REDCap data are stored on an approved third-party infrastructure operating under contractual and governance arrangements with the University. System administration, user management, and governance oversight are performed by designated University REDCap administrators.
REDCap supports compliance with data protection and research governance requirements by enabling controlled access, auditability, and structured data management. Responsibility for lawful data collection, ethical approval, and appropriate data use remains with the project owner and the institution.
Use in research and ethics-approved projects
REDCap is widely used internationally for ethically approved research and operational data collection, including studies involving personal and sensitive data. Its design supports good research data management practices, including transparency, accountability, and data security.
